<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>

<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_NetworkGetHostName_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_NetworkGetHostName_Impl(char *host_name, size_t name_len)
{
    int32 return_code;

    if (gethostname(host_name, name_len) < 0)
    {
        return_code = OS_ERROR;
    }
    else
    {
        /*
         * posix does not say that the name is always
         * null terminated, so its worthwhile to ensure it
         */
        host_name[name_len - 1] = 0;
        return_code             = OS_SUCCESS;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No controlling expressions in this function are invariant. The only conditional is if (gethostname(host_name, name_len) < 0) — its value depends on the runtime result of gethostname and therefore is not a compile-time or loop-invariant constant. There are no loops (for, while, do-while) whose controlling expressions could be invariant, and no other conditional expressions present. The assignment host_name[name_len - 1] = 0 and the return statements are not controlling expressions and thus not relevant to Rule 14.3. Therefore there are no fragments that require investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3.
